headline: Block lays off nearly half its staff because of AI. Its CEO said most companies will do the same
summary: Block, the company behind Square, Cash App and Afterpay, is cutting its staff by 40%. The reason: “intelligence tools,” according to a letter to shareholders by co-founder Jack Dorsey.

headline: Amazon’s OpenAI Bet, Antitrust Pressure And AI Turnover Weigh On Valuation
summary: Amazon.com (NasdaqGS:AMZN) is reportedly in talks to invest up to US$50b in OpenAI, a move that could make it the AI firm’s largest backer. California’s attorney general is seeking a preliminary injunction in an antitrust case that challenges Amazon’s alleged retail price controls in the US. David Luan, a key executive in Amazon’s artificial intelligence division, has resigned, marking a leadership change in a core technology area. For you as an investor, this mix of AI expansion, legal...

headline: Texas at heart of Amazon's AI push in United States
summary: Tech titan Amazon is working to step out of Nvidia's shadow with custom "Trainium" chips designed specially for machine learning as billions of dollars are poured into artificial intelligence (AI).After years of relying on suppliers for chips, the e-commerce powerhouse's Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud computing unit began designing its own, acquiring Israeli startup Annapurna Labs in 2015.

content.title: Texas at heart of Amazon's AI push in United States
content.summary: Tech titan Amazon is working to step out of Nvidia's shadow with custom "Trainium" chips designed specially for machine learning as billions of dollars are poured into artificial intelligence (AI).After years of relying on suppliers for chips, the e-commerce powerhouse's Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud computing unit began designing its own, acquiring Israeli startup Annapurna Labs in 2015.

thumbnail.caption: Amazon is powering artificial intelligence with custom Trainium chips designed especially for maching learning (Mark Felix)

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Shifts As Buffett Exits And Abel Faces New Tests
summary: Warren Buffett is retiring as CEO of Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRK.B), with Greg Abel set to succeed him. Berkshire has adjusted its equity portfolio, selling holdings in Apple, Bank of America, and Amazon.com. The company has added to positions in Chevron and Chubb and opened a new stake in The New York Times Company. A Berkshire utility subsidiary has agreed to a substantial settlement to resolve federal wildfire damage claims. Berkshire is also selling certain assets to support balance...

content.title: Berkshire Hathaway Shifts As Buffett Exits And Abel Faces New Tests

headline: Nvidia Fails to Reassure—Heard on the Street Thursday Recap
summary: Nvidia’s shares fell 5.5% despite record income as investors continue to set a high bar for AI bellwethers.  One problem, notes Heard columnist Dan Gallagher, is that the company’s runaway success could be seen as a sign of destabilization to come, given that the capital spending filling its coffers is financially weakening some of the world’s largest companies, from Amazon to Microsoft.  The Nasdaq and S&P 500 declined following Nvidia's slide, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average was little changed and Treasury yields inched lower.

content.title: Nvidia Fails to Reassure—Heard on the Street Thursday Recap
content.summary: Nvidia’s shares fell 5.5% despite record income as investors continue to set a high bar for AI bellwethers.  One problem, notes Heard columnist Dan Gallagher, is that the company’s runaway success could be seen as a sign of destabilization to come, given that the capital spending filling its coffers is financially weakening some of the world’s largest companies, from Amazon to Microsoft.  The Nasdaq and S&P 500 declined following Nvidia's slide, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average was little changed and Treasury yields inched lower.

headline: Nvidia Looks Like a Value Stock Even as Earnings Scream Growth
summary: The stock is priced at about 22 times forward earnings, well below its five-year average of 37 and barely above the S&P 500’s multiple.  “There’s something of a disconnect between how strong the results were and the stock not doing better,” said Robert Pavlik, senior portfolio manager at Dakota Wealth Management, which owns Nvidia shares.

content.title: Nvidia Looks Like a Value Stock Even as Earnings Scream Growth
content.summary: The stock is priced at about 22 times forward earnings, well below its five-year average of 37 and barely above the S&P 500’s multiple.  “There’s something of a disconnect between how strong the results were and the stock not doing better,” said Robert Pavlik, senior portfolio manager at Dakota Wealth Management, which owns Nvidia shares.
